head.title: National Briefing | Washington: The Wheat Wars

hedline.hl1: National Briefing | Washington: The Wheat Wars

abstract.p: United States Trade Rep Robert B Zoellick, responding to complaints from North Dakota farmers, charges monopoly practices by Canadian Wheat Board, government trading group, undercut American wheat producers; weighs complaint to World Trade Organization and filing antidumping petition with Commerce Department; imports of Canadian hard red spring wheat increased by 300,000 metric tons in last two years (S)

block.p: Responding to complaints from North Dakota farmers, the United States trade representative accused Canada of undercutting American wheat producers through monopoly practices by the Canadian Wheat Board, a government trading group. The comments by the trade representative, Robert B. Zoellick, came after a 16-month investigation. Mr. Zoellick said he was considering bringing the case before the World Trade Organization as well as filing antidumping petitions with the Department of Commerce. Imports of Canadian hard red spring wheat increased by 300,000 metric tons in the last two years.

Responding to complaints from North Dakota farmers, the United States trade representative accused Canada of undercutting American wheat producers through monopoly practices by the Canadian Wheat Board, a government trading group. The comments by the trade representative, Robert B. Zoellick, came after a 16-month investigation. Mr. Zoellick said he was considering bringing the case before the World Trade Organization as well as filing antidumping petitions with the Department of Commerce. Imports of Canadian hard red spring wheat increased by 300,000 metric tons in the last two years.
